title: 108_s676
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS; PURPOSE." is a concise summary of the section's main components. The Act is titled the "World Trade Organization Dispute Settlement Review Commission Act" and aims to protect US sovereignty within the global trading system overseen by the WTO. The dispute settlement rules of the WTO are designed to ensure governments adhere to their obligations. The United States supports the WTO for mutual trade benefits and effective remedies against unfair practices. Congress passed the Uruguay Round Agreements Act to maintain trade remedies essential for opening foreign markets and protecting American industries. WTO dispute panels and the Appellate Body should operate fairly and impartially. The purpose of the WTO Dispute Settlement Review Commission is to ensure fair and impartial operation, uphold Uruguay Round Agreements, and adhere to WTO standards. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, an "adverse finding" refers to a panel or Appellate Body decision that a law or regulation of the United States is inconsistent with its obligations under a Uruguay Round Agreement, or that a measure of a party complained against is not inconsistent with their obligations. The terms defined in this section include "affirmative report," "Appellate Body," "Dispute Settlement Body," and "dispute settlement panel." These terms are crucial for understanding the dispute resolution process outlined in the Act. The terms "dispute settlement panel," "Dispute Settlement Understanding," "terms of reference," "Trade Representative," and "Uruguay Round Agreement" are defined in relation to international trade agreements. The terms "World Trade Organization" and "WTO" refer to the organization established under the WTO Agreement on April 15, 1994. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT OF COMMISSION. Establishment of the World Trade Organization Dispute Settlement Review Commission, composed of 5 retired judges appointed by the President in consultation with various congressional leaders. Appointments to be made within 90 days of enactment of the Act. The World Trade Organization Dispute Settlement Review Commission will consist of 5 retired judges appointed by the President in consultation with congressional leaders. Members will serve staggered terms of 5, 3, or 2 years, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Meetings will be held as necessary. The World Trade Organization Dispute Settlement Review Commission will have 5 retired judges appointed by the President. Meetings will be held within 30 days of all members being appointed, with subsequent meetings called by the chairperson. A majority of members will constitute a quorum, and a chairperson and vice chairperson will be selected from among the members. An affirmative vote by a majority of members is required for any determination under section 4. The World Trade Organization Dispute Settlement Review Commission will have 5 retired judges appointed by the President. Meetings will be held within 30 days of all members being appointed, with subsequent meetings called by the chairperson. A majority of members will constitute a quorum, and a chairperson and vice chairperson will be selected from among the members. An affirmative vote by a majority of members is required for any determination under section 4. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The World Trade Organization Dispute Settlement Review Commission will review adverse reports from WTO panels or the Appellate Body, upon request. The scope of review includes reports adopted by the Dispute Settlement Body. The World Trade Organization Dispute Settlement Review Commission conducts a complete review to determine if panels or the Appellate Body exceeded authority, added or diminished US rights under the Uruguay Round Agreement, acted arbitrarily, engaged in misconduct, or deviated from applicable standards of review. The World Trade Organization Dispute Settlement Review Commission reviews cases of unfair trade remedies under specific standards outlined in the Agreement on Implementation of Article VI of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, 1994. If the Commission makes an affirmative determination regarding a panel or Appellate Body's action, it assesses whether it materially affected the outcome of the report within 120 days of its adoption by the Dispute Settlement Body. The Commission will issue a written determination on matters in subsection (a) (2) and (3), and report it to the House Ways and Means Committee and Senate Finance Committee. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather testimony and evidence, and provide notice for hearings. The Trade Representative must inform the Commission of adverse panel or Appellate Body reports and allow interested parties to submit comments. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather testimony, and receive submissions from interested parties regarding panel or Appellate Body reports. The Trade Representative must provide the Commission with relevant documents and information upon request. The Trade Representative must provide relevant documents to the Commission, which will be available to the public except for proprietary or confidential information. Federal agencies can provide support services to assist the Commission in its functions. The Commission will protect confidential documents from disclosure and is not considered an agency for purposes of section 552 of title 5, United States Code.
